questions.text: Which of the following combination of biomedical waste management is correct regarding the disposal of an Expired tablet?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:

Option C. Yellow bag - incineration

Explanation:

Biomedical waste, including expired tablets and pharmaceuticals, needs to be disposed of properly to prevent environmental contamination and health hazards. The correct method for the disposal of expired tablets is incineration, which ensures complete destruction of the pharmaceutical substances.

  • Yellow bag - incineration: Yellow bags or containers are used for the collection of biomedical waste that requires incineration. This waste includes pharmaceuticals, chemicals, and other hazardous materials. Incineration is a high-temperature process that destroys the drugs, reducing the chance of environmental contamination.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Red bag - hydroclaving: Red bags typically signify medical waste that is potentially infectious. Hydroclaving is a method that uses high-pressure steam to sterilize infectious waste, but it may not be the ideal method for pharmaceutical disposal, especially for large quantities like expired tablets.

Option B. Blue bag - incineration: Blue bags are often used for recyclable materials. Incineration is the correct method for pharmaceutical disposal, but blue bags are not typically associated with biomedical waste disposal.

Option D. Yellow bag - burial: Burial of pharmaceuticals or biomedical waste is not a recommended or acceptable method of disposal due to the risk of groundwater contamination and environmental pollution.

questions.text: As per biomedical waste management guidelines, in which colored bag should used pacemakers be discarded?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Blue

Explanation:

  • According to the Biomedical Waste Management Guidelines, used pacemakers should be disposed of in the blue colored bag, which is designated for non-infectious, recyclable, and discarded electronics.
  • The blue bag is typically used for items like discarded electronics, including pacemakers, that are not considered hazardous or infectious but need to be disposed of safely due to their electronic and metal components.

 

Yellow (Optio A): Yellow bags are used for infectious waste such as human tissues, body fluids, and soiled items.

White (Option B): White bags are typically used for glassware and items that are non-infectious but still require careful disposal.

Black (Option C): Black bags are used for general waste that is non-hazardous, but pacemakers are classified under non-infectious medical waste that needs special handling.

Correct Answer Option A - Yellow bag

Explanation:

  • Cytotoxic drugs, also known as antineoplastic or chemotherapy drugs, are disposed of in a specialized yellow bag. These drugs are considered hazardous substances due to their toxic properties. The yellow bag is designed specifically for collecting and disposing hazardous or cytotoxic waste, including unused or expired drugs, empty drug vials, IV tubing, and other items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs.

Color

Type of waste

Example of waste

Treatment and disposal

Yellow (Option A)
  • Human anatomical waste.
  • Animal anatomical waste.
  • Soiled waste.
  • Discarded or expired medicine.
  • Microbiology, biotechnology and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Chemical waste.
  • Chemical liquid waste.

 
  • Placenta.
  • Post-operative body parts.
  • Plaster of Paris (POP).
  • Pathological waste.
  • Cotton waste.
  • Dressing materials.
  • Beddings.
  • Body fluid contaminated paper and cloth.
  • Face mask, cap, shoe cover and head cover.
  • Cytotoxic, expired and discarded medicines.
  • Microbiology and biotechnology lab waste.
  • Blood bag
  • Vacutainers with blood
  • Incineration.
  • Plasma pyrolysis.
  • Deep burial.

 

Red (Option B ruled out)
  • Contaminated waste that is recyclable.
  • Syringe without needles.
  • Fixed needle syringes with their needle cut.
  • IV set.
  • Catheters.
  • Gloves (soiled or unsoiled).
  • Urine bag.
  • Dialysis kit.
  • IV bottles.
  • Tubing's.
  • Bottles.
  • Vacutainers with needle cuts.
  • Vacutainers without blood.
  • ELISA plates and vials not containing blood samples.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/ hydroclaving followed by shredding or mutilation and waste set to registered recyclers or for energy recovery/road making.
  • Plastic waste should not be sent to landfill sites.

White

Waste Sharps
  • Needles
  • Syringes with fixed needles
  • Blades
  • Scalpers
  • Trocar cannula
  • Insulin pen needle
  • Puncture proof , Leak proof, Tamper proof containers
  • Autoclaving or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding or mutilation or encapsulation in metal container or cement concrete
  • Or sent for final disposal to iron foundries or sanitary landfills or designated concrete waste sharp pit

 

Blue (Option C ruled out)

Glassware or metallic body implants.
  • Includes broken or discarded glass and metallic objects that are contaminated.
  • Glass:
    • Broken glass.
    • Ampoules.
    • Lab slide
  • Metals:
    • Nails.
    • Metallic body implants.
    • Scissors.
    • Artificial pacemakers.
  • Cardboard boxes with blue colored markings or blue coloured puncture-proof and tamper-proof containers.
  • Disinfection (cleaning with detergent and soaking in sodium hypochlorite) or autoclaving or microwaving or hydroclaving and then sent for recycling.

 

Black bag (Option D): Black bags are commonly used for general waste or municipal solid waste that does not require specialized handling or disposal. Similar to blue bags, black bags are not appropriate for the disposal of cytotoxic drugs due to their hazardous nature.

questions.text: Which of the options below could have been discarded in the white bag by the compounder as biomedical waste?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Sharp waste

Explanation:

  • Biomedical wastes disposed of in white bags contain sharps. They are not pretreated and they are recycled or reused after shredding.

 

Colour

Waste Type

Type of bag or container to be used

Method of disposal

Yellow
  • All infectious waste.
  • Human anatomical waste. (Option A ruled out)
  • Animal anatomical waste
  • Soiled waste (contaminated with blood, body fluids, dressings and swabs, blood bags).
  • Expired or discarded medicines
  • Chemical waste.
  • Microbiological and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Yellow coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Incineration
  • Plasma pyrolysis
  • Deep burial

Red
  • Contaminated waste (recyclable): Tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), vacutainers and gloves. (Option D ruled out)
  • Red coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill).

Blue
  • Glassware: Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste. (Option C ruled out)
  • Metallic body implants.
  • Cardboard boxes with blue coloured markings.
  • Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling.

White
  • Waste sharps including metals: Needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels or any other sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. (Option B)
  • Puncture proof and leak proof containers.
  • Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation.

questions.text: In which of the following should a cotton swab with pus be discarded?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Yellow non-chlorination bag

Explanation:

Cotton swab with pus = soiled waste (items contaminated with blood, body fluids, pus, etc.).

  • Soiled waste → Yellow category (non-chlorinated plastic bags).
  • Chlorination is avoided for biodegradable waste like cotton, gauze, bandages, etc., as these are incinerated.

Biomedical Waste Management Summary

  • Fetus, organ, tissue, soiled cotton, gauze, dressing, bandages, casts, plasters, IUD, expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic waste, body secretions e.g. sputum, pus, feces, X-ray developer fluids, disinfectants, linens, beddings, mattress, gowns, culture plates, blood bags, blood transfusion sets, live vaccine vial, blood products, masks, shoe cover, head cover: Yellow bag for incineration, plasma pyrolysis, and deep burial.
  • Recyclable plastics, tubes, vacutainers without blood, syringes without needles, urobags, catheters, Ryle's tubes, IV drip sets, face shields, goggles: Red bag.
  • Sharps and other metals: White bag.
  • Orthopaedic implants, glassware, artificial pacemaker: Blue bag.

Yellow chlorination bag (Option A): Not used; yellow category waste is incinerated, so chlorination is unnecessary.

Red chlorination bag (Option C): The red category is for contaminated recyclable waste (e.g., tubing, catheters), not soiled waste.

Red non-chlorination bag (Option D): Still incorrect category for pus-soaked cotton.

questions.text: Which among the following logos will be seen in a contaminated biomedical waste management plant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Biohazard symbol

Explanation:

  • A contaminated biomedical waste management plant handles infectious and hazardous materials → marked with the biohazard logo
  • This symbol is internationally recognized for infectious agents and materials that pose a threat to humans or the environment.

Universal recycling symbol (Option B): Used for recyclable materials, not related to infectious waste.

Radiation hazard symbol (Option C): Indicates radioactive materials

High voltage symbol (Option D): Warns of electrical hazards, not used for waste categorization.

questions.text: During a field visit to monitor training given to an ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife) on safe immunization practices, you observe that she has used a syringe with a needle, a vaccine vial, and a cotton swab. After completing the immunization, which of the following statements about biomedical waste disposal is correct?

choices.text: The syringe with the needle should be disposed of in a black translucent container
The used vaccine vial should be discarded in a blue bag
A used cotton swab should be discarded in a red bag
The needle should be bent and thrown in a red bag

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. The used vaccine vial should be discarded in a blue bag

Explanation:

  • Used or expired vaccine vials are considered glass waste and are disposed of in puncture-proof blue containers or blue bags for recycling or proper treatment.
  • Syringes with needles go into white translucent puncture-proof containers without removing the needle, cotton swabs with blood/body fluids go in yellow bags, and needles should never be bent or broken before disposal, as it increases the risk of needle-stick injury.

Item

Waste Category

Disposal Container/Bag

Notes

Syringe with needle

Sharps

White translucent container (puncture-proof)

Needle not removed, container disinfected before disposal

Used vaccine vial (glass)

Glass waste

Blue puncture-proof box/bag

After ensuring vial is empty/expired

Cotton swab (contaminated)

Infectious waste

Yellow bag

If with blood/body fluids

Plastic syringe without needle

Contaminated recyclable

Red bag

For autoclaving/microwaving before recycling

Biomedical Waste Management Summary

  • Fetus, organ, tissue, soiled cotton, gauze, dressings, bandages, casts, plasters, IUD, expired/discarded medicines, cytotoxic waste, body secretions e.g. sputum, pus, feces, X-ray developer fluids, disinfectants, linens, beddings, mattress, gowns, culture plates, blood bags, blood transfusion sets, live vaccine vial, blood products, masks, shoe cover, head cover: Yellow bag for incineration, plasma pyrolysis, and deep burial.
  • Recyclable plastics, tubes, vacutainers without blood, syringes without needles, urobags, catheters, Ryle's tubes, IV drip sets, face shields, goggles: Red bag.
  • Sharps and other metals: White bag.
  • Orthopaedic implants, glassware, artificial pacemaker: Blue bag.

The syringe with the needle should be disposed of in a black translucent container (Option A): Incorrect; sharps go into white translucent puncture-proof containers, not black. Black is for discarded medicines, cytotoxic drugs, or general waste in older systems, but not for sharps under current BMWM rules.

A used cotton swab should be discarded in a red bag (Option C): Incorrect; contaminated cotton swabs go in yellow bags, not red. Red is for contaminated recyclable plastic items.

The needle should be bent and thrown in a red bag (Option D): Incorrect and unsafe; bending needles increases needle-stick risk and sharps never go into red bags.
